content: I'm not sure the result is correct. It doesn't take into account the initale 1m/s speed specified in the text

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is easy and fun

Comment: It actually is not rocket science!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it rocket sci-fi version =)). I accepted it because it requires participants to understand a real problem and convert it to code. It is an important skill that should be tested in contests.

(P/M I only test it in Js. Asking me to test in all languages doesn't make sense. Not many people can actually do that right)
I like the joke, but I'm pretty sure the title isn't visible during a clash.  None of the text is visible in reverse mode, so it would just look like a super easy puzzle.

It sure isn't rocket science as rockets normally accelerate continuously, not discretely once a second. You could make it more like a real rocket by starting it at 0m/s with continuous acceleration, that way your solution still works.

You should give an upper bound for n, perhaps 10000. Enough to get your rocket to orbit, without integer overflows.

If the puzzle was realistic about the physics (e.g. increasing acceleration as the mass decreases), then it WOULD be rocket science - and require far too much non-coding knowledge for a 15-minute clash.
Just read murrayr's comment. You can't write "constant acceleration" if you mean "discrete boosts every second".
